intro: Tapeinosperma pachycaulum, commonly known as the thick-stemmed sand mat, is a low-growing perennial plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It has a dense, cushion-like growth form with small, fleshy, blue-green leaves that help reduce water loss in its harsh environment. The plant produces small, white to pale purple flowers that bloom in spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its thick, fleshy stems store water, allowing it to survive prolonged droughts. It is often found in sandy soils and is an important component of desert ecosystems.
